abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. This rating is
            based on the fulfillment of economic objectives, completion
            of the physical components, and, a satisfactory current
            operation. In addition, the development of the regulatory
            framework, exceeded project expectations. The key lessons
            suggest that, although some implementation problems could
            have been solved with more detailed preparation, and
            identification of training needs, the strong Project
            Implementation Unit conveyed the responsibility, through
            staff continuity, required for changing circumstances.
            Supervision cost effectiveness succeeded, in that, due to
            the modest project size (relative to its budget, supervision
            costs can be substantial), individual consultants were
            hired, instead of the more expensive approach of a company,
            with the traditional and permanent field staff. It is
            suggested that financing arrangements, when multiple
            co-financiers are involved, should spell out the
            parties' commitments, nominal fees, and withdrawal
            penalties, and, be made a condition for negotiations, if
            possible. When leverage is high, the Bank should front-load
            the implementation of institutional, and environmental
            project components, addressing these early on during project
            execution, and, conditions of effectiveness should be
            predictable to uncertainties, such as spelling out
            contracting conditions, to reduce associated risks.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Power Development Project
            (Power II) will cover Belize Electricity Limited's
            (BEL) medium-term (1997-2005) power and transmission
            requirements. The project will comprise: (a) the
            construction of a 115 kV interconnection transmission system
            running from the border with Mexico to Belize City; (b) the
            integration of San Pedro (the major tourist area of the
            country) to the system; (c) the integration of Dangriga (the
            principal area of the citrus industry) to the system; (d)
            dispatch center, supervisory control, data acquisition and
            communications for system operations; (e) an environmental
            mitigation program for the existing diesel plants; and (f)
            consulting services to assist BEL in engineering and project
            management, and technical assistance and training.
